instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message:
Hey! I have this board that came in with no power. Short on PPBUS was .1 in diode. <CAPACITOR>C7341</CAPACITOR> was getting very hot. I removed and now have .132 in diode on PPBUS. Same goes for <SIGNAL>S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL>. PPDCIN is 16.8V.
Hoping the CPU is not dead, please advise on finding this short so that, I myself dont fuck it up being so close to CPU.

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message: PPBUS to GND resistance? Measure PPBUS to all coils to check for shorted high side FETs. PPBUS present at all?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message:
PPBUS to GND from pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R4260</RESISTOR> is .001 OHMs. PPBUS to coils L7550, L7510 and L7520 is .002 OHMs. PPBUS is 1.9V. Thanks Duke.

(PPBUS diode measurement from first post is incorrect. Sorry. )


******Scratch this entire post. I was in wrong mode. Be back with correct measurements. Ugh... Sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message:
OK, Here are correct measurement. 

PPBUS to GND - 1.9 Ohms
PPBUS to L7550 - 2.7 Ohms
                 L7510 - 3.1 Ohms
                 L7520 - 3.1 Ohms
                 L7630 - 11.7 Ohms

PPBUS is 1.920 V 

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message: Doesn't seem like a shorted FET. Inject power and see if anything heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message: Hi! Injected power and found <CAPACITOR>C7340</CAPACITOR> getting hot, though this was not the short I was looking for. Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7340</CAPACITOR> and injected power again. This time the board is not drawing current. Voltage set to 3.5-5V and Amps stuck at 0. Only left it on for a couple mins. Any thoughts? Thanks, have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message: If <CAPACITOR>C7340</CAPACITOR> got hot when injecting voltage on PPBUS then the DDR rail already saw 12V so the CPU is probably fried.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message: Ok Duke. Anything else I can do to confirm? Thank you. Btw, PPBUS does read the 3.5v being injected on multimeter. Not sure if this matters.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS Short
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C7340</CAPACITOR> got hot so <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR> will be shorted, check it. If it is shorted then this is probably trash.
